page.title: 16HEALTH
page.content: {The sewage works.}On Wednesday 22nd May we went to the sewage works in Carters Lane. Mr Parrott showed us around and told us the sewage from all our Woking drains comes to these works and is purified. The water that is clean enough goes back into the river. The first job at the works is to remove rags, wood, and large objects which could damage the machinery. Grit and sand gets into the drains from roads and gardens. As it can wear out pumps very quickly it is removed, washed, dredged, and buried. After that the sewage flows into primary sedimentation tanks where the solids will settle to the bottom. The liquid that is left over is taken to the secondary treatment plant. Special microbes are grown which feed on the sewage. They destroy harmful germs and leave only water and gas.
